Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 43188  
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
Addressing the Pre- and Postharvest Challenges of 
the Rice Supply Chain  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ANRR  –  agriculture and natural resources research 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  IARCs  –  International agriculture research centers 
  IRRI  –  International Rice Research Institute 
  NARES  –  national agriculture research and extension systems 
  NGO  –  nongovernment organization 
  PRC  –  People's Republic of China 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General Intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Agriculture and natural resources (agricultural production and 
markets) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (knowledge, science, and technological

NOTE

Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss,  Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Director General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Unit Head  K. Matsunami, Agriculture, Rural Development, and Food Security Unit, RSDD 
   
Team leader  L. Adriano, Principal Agriculture Sector Specialist, RSDD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has supported agriculture and natural resources 
research (ANRR) by the Consultative Group on International Agriculture Research and other 
international agriculture research centers since the adoption of the ADB's ANRR policy paper1 in 
1995. To date, 13 regional technical assistance (RETA) grants have been provided. A special 
evaluation study of the ANRR policy2 noted the high economic returns on investments of the 
ANRR RETA grants and recommended that ADB continue to support ANRR.  
2.  The Thirteenth Agriculture and Natural Resources Research at International Agricultural 
Research Centers (ANRR RETA 13) was a response to the 2008 global food crisis.3 ANRR 
RETA 13 is consistent with ADB's Strategy 2020 as it addresses food security as an underlying 
element of the inclusive growth strategy.4 One of its components was designed to increase rice 
production by reducing pest and disease outbreaks and by supporting appropriate postharvest 
technologies.  The  adoption  and  adaptation  of  appropriate  pre-  and  postharvest  rice 
technologies and practices will take at least 5 years before having a visible impact on the rice 
market. Acknowledging the length of this gestation period for technology development and 
dissemination, the RETA included a provision that "ADB may provide additional subsequent 
funding support … subject to its initial success and the availability of funds." 
3.   The  proposed  research  and  development  TA5 will  continue  and  build  on  the  work 
initiated in ANRR RETA 13, specifically on the adoption and adaptation of pre- and postharvest 
technologies and practices.   
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Food prices rose sharply in 2007 and 2008 and the rise in the export price of rice more 
than tripled between November 2007 and March 2008. Rice stocks dropped to below the 
internationally accepted threshold of 20% of global production. These developments, coupled 
with the world financial recession, adversely affected Asia’s poor, who spend as much as 
30%−40% of their income on rice. In Asia, more than 480 million people (nearly 70% of its poor) 
are rice producers and consumers of rice as a staple. Ensuring stable prices and enhanced 
productivity and profitability of rice are thus integral to reducing poverty.   
5.  The immediate challenge for 2010–2015 is how to increase the global rice supply to 
meet rising demand and replenish existing rice stocks. Increasing rice production is a major 
challenge as the effects of climate change in Asia (including the potential for plant hopper 
outbreaks induced by rising temperatures) intensify.6 Intensive cropping systems are likely to be 
particularly affected as plant hopper outbreaks are also associated with overuse of fertilizers 
and  pesticides.  In  2009,  such  outbreaks  increased  significantly,  with  citings  reported  from

Bangladesh,  Cambodia,  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  India,  Republic  of  Korea, 
Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam.  These outbreaks may have implications for 
rice production and food security, since India, Thailand, and Viet Nam are major global suppliers 
of rice. 
6.  Rice supplies can be increased in the short term by closing the yield gaps of 1 to 2 tons 
per hectare that can be found in most irrigated rice farm fields in Asia.7 This gap can be closed 
through measures to prevent pre- and postharvest losses, such as ecologically based crop 
management practices that prevent pests (such as plant hoppers) during the pre-harvest stage. 
These practices involve increasing the diversity of the predators and parasitoids that regulate 
pests and reducing the use of fertilizers and insecticides by more than 50%.8  
7.  Rice supply can also be increased by reducing grain losses at the postharvest stage. 
About 5%–6% of rice is lost due to poor cutting, handling, threshing, and cleaning. Another 5%–
21% is lost because of inadequate drying, storage, milling, and processing facilities. The total 
estimated losses are 10%–37% of all rice grown. If rice farmers can reduce their postharvest 
losses, their incomes will increase as the quantity and quality of their marketed rice improve. 
Rice consumers will also benefit as the rice they consume improves in quality and prices drop.  
8.  As a response to the global food crisis in 2008, the International Rice Research Institute 
(IRRI)  developed  a  5-year  pre-  and  postharvest  program  with  the  aim  of  increasing  rice 
availability by 5% from 2008 levels by 2015 in selected Asian countries.9 ADB supported the 
program's start-up costs through ANRR RETA 13, and may provide additional support if the 
program is successful and funds are available.  
9.  The  semiannual  progress  report  from  IRRI  on  the  status  of  its  first  year  pre-  and 
postharvest activities under ANRR RETA 13 documented the initial achievements. Some 92 
national  agriculture  research  and  extension  systems  (NARES)  conducting  ecological, 
toxicological and sociological research are involved in the collection and analysis of baseline 
data that will be used to develop new seeds that are resistant to pests and virus outbreaks. 
Standardized research methods in ecology, toxicology and sociology have been established 
and  the  protocols  are  available  online  in  the  blog  developed  under  ANRR  RETA  13 
(http://Ricehoppers.net). The blog, which has attracted more than 14,000 visitors from all over 
the world, provides a platform for sharing information and analysis. A database for effective 
monitoring and impact assessments has also been set up. Initial results show that some farmers 
in the PRC and Viet Nam whose lands are adjacent to the pilot fields have tried out these 
ecological engineering crop management practices.   
10.  IRRI, in partnership with farmers, nongovernment organizations (NGOs), and the private 
sector, has developed a suite of technology prototypes that are designed to reduce the losses 
and  improve  the  quantity  of  grains.  In  2009,  needs  assessments  and  participatory  impact 
pathway  analyses  were  conducted  in  participating  developing  member  countries  (DMCs), 
involving various stakeholders. National learning alliances, which will help to build partnerships 
with many stakeholders, have already been set up. The development of business models and 
technology-specific extension approaches has already started in Cambodia and Viet Nam. 
Some private local manufacturers, in partnership with farmers' groups in these countries, have

11.  The proposed technical assistance will continue the activities planned for and initiated in 
the pre- and postharvest component of the ongoing ANRR RETA 13. It will provide support to 
ensure that better pest management practices and postharvest technologies and management 
options are pilot tested, validated, and tailored to particular socioeconomic and agronomic 
conditions. It will ensure that many stakeholders (and rural women in particular) are engaged 
before pilots are scaled up.  
12.  As in ANRR RETA 13, the design of the proposed technical assistance incorporates the 
lessons learned from previous ADB-funded RETA projects on ANRR, including the need to  
(i) strengthen the capacity of national agriculture research systems; (ii) improve links among 
researchers, practitioners, and policy makers to improve the dissemination of research findings; 
and  (iii)  strengthen  ADB's  capacity  to  coordinate,  supervise,  monitor,  and  evaluate  ANRR 
activities. The proposed TA will also increase the participation of women in pre- and postharvest 
activities because of their critical role in implementing and disseminating agriculture innovations 
and practices.   
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact will be increased rice availability in the project sites of Cambodia, the PRC, 
the  Philippines,  Thailand,  and  Viet  Nam.  Appendix  1  contains  the  design  and  monitoring 
framework. The expected outcome will be an increase in rice farmers' capacity to reduce pre-
harvest and postharvest losses in the project sites of participating DMCs.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  For the subproject on reducing pre-harvest losses, the key outputs will be: (i) a new field 
resistance screening method and germplasm with durable field resistance to plant hoppers and 
viruses  developed  and  disseminated;  (ii)  strategies  to  manage  virus  spreads  in  rice  fields 
developed  and  implemented  in  project  sites;  (iii)  ecologically  based  management  of  pest 
outbreaks implemented  on  a  pilot  basis;  (iv)  country-specific  strategies  to  manage  viruses 
implemented; and (v) research and extension capacities of NARES partners improved. To 
achieve these outputs, the key activities will be: disseminating genetic stock information and 
plant hopper screening procedures to all NARES partners; conducting analysis of gender roles 
in the use of ecological engineering methods for non-rice habitats; implementing ecologically 
based management of pest outbreaks in project sites; training NARES scientists and other 
technical staff on ecological engineering, and biodiversity and ecosystems services analysis;  
and engaging in policy dialogues in support of gender-sensitive ecological based management.  
15.  For  the  subproject  on  reducing  postharvest  losses,  the  key  outputs  will  be:  
(i) appropriate postharvest technologies and management options developed, locally produced, 
and distributed; (ii) agricultural extension and/or advisory services for postharvest technology 
and  practices  suitable  for  local  environments  prepared;  (iii)  business  models  for  improved 
postharvest technologies developed and verified on a pilot basis; and (iv) a national postharvest 
network involving many stakeholders strengthened. The key activities will include: carrying out 
adaptive research on postharvest technologies; piloting and developing business models on 
public–private  partnerships  on  postharvest  extension  services;  building  on  modalities  for

4   
sustainable  learning  alliances  (including  networks  of  women)  on  postharvest  technologies; 
training of men and women farmer intermediaries on extension systems; promoting market 
awareness; and enhancing technology transfer.  
16.  A participatory process involving many stakeholders will be employed in the pre- and 
postharvest subprojects. The process will engage the NARES, local and national governments, 
the private sector, farmers' groups, and NGOs in facilitating the adoption and adaptation of 
technologies and practices, identifying capacity building and policy gaps, participating in training 
and policy dialogue, and monitoring and providing feedback on project activities and outputs.   
17.  The key assumptions are that (i) local and national governments in DMCs will support 
the scaling up of pre- and post harvest technologies and practices, (ii) trained NARES staff will 
not shift careers, and (iii) IRRI is able to mobilize additional funds for the remaining activities of 
its  pre-  and  postharvest  program.  The  risks  include:  (i)  local  elites  capture  postharvest 
technologies, (ii) farmers are unable to adopt the technologies, and (iii) regulatory measures 
discourage the adoption of the technologies. The TA will address these concerns through policy 
reforms  and  communication  mechanisms  that  (i)  advocate  for  increased  and  sustained 
government budgets for agriculture research; (ii) remove restrictive measures that hamper the 
use of pre- and postharvest technologies and practices; and (iii) disseminate these technologies 
and practices widely. Before the end of the project, IRRI and ADB will assess and explore 
options for funding the pre- and postharvest program, including a supplementary TA.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.0 million equivalent, and will be financed on a grant basis 
from ADB's TA Special Fund (TASF IV and TASF-other sources). Detailed cost estimates and a 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
IV.  IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 
19.  The TA is expected to be implemented from January 2010 to December 2011. ADB 
through  its  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  (Agriculture,  Rural 
Development, and Food Security Unit) will be the executing agency. The unit will oversee the 
implementation of the TA. It will regularly monitor the TA progress in achieving the desired 
impact, outcome, outputs, and activities in a timely manner. The funding and implementation of 
the TA are subject to receipt of no-objection letters from the participating DMCs:  Cambodia, the 
PRC, the Philippines, Thailand, and Viet Nam.  
20.  The TA will be implemented by IRRI, which will be engaged through single-source 
selection  in  accordance  with  the  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  Single-source  selection  is  justified  because  IRRI  is  uniquely 
qualified to develop pre- and postharvest measures that can help reduce the rice yield gap in 
rice-growing  Asian  economies.  IRRI  is  recognized  globally  as  the  leading  center  for  rice 
research and extension. It has about 50 years of experience in cutting-edge research on rice-
related knowledge and technology, has extensive regional rice-based research infrastructure, 
has a critical mass of scientists and can easily access appropriate experts with multidisciplinary 
knowledge on key rice-based agro-ecosystems, and has global and regional research networks 
with established links to the NARES.  
21.  IRRI will implement the TA under the supervision of ADB. It will be responsible for (i)  the 
timely delivery of quality outputs of the experts; (ii) the conduct of training, seminars and

5
conferences; (iii) undertaking the surveys and regular monitoring and evaluation of the TA's 
activities in achieving the TA's outputs, outcome, and impact; and (iv) for the reports and other 
communication related TA activities. It will hold an inception workshop within 2 months of the 
TA's approval to confirm the activities and milestones for each intended output of the pre- and 
postharvest subprojects. The midterm and final workshops will be held within 12 months and 21 
months of TA approval, respectively. IRRI will submit the following reports to ADB: (i) an 
inception report; (ii) two semiannual progress reports, (iii) a midterm progress report; (iv) a final 
completion  report;  (v)  semiannual  financial  statements;  and  (vi)  audited  annual  financial 
statements.    
22.  IRRI will provide about 59 person-months of international experts and 74 person-months 
of national experts in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time).. The expert needs are: an insect ecologist and team leader for the 
pre-harvest  subproject,  a  postharvest  systems  expert  and  team  leader  for  the postharvest 
subproject, a virologist, an international and a national insect toxicologist, a taxonomist, a 
training specialist, a local postharvest systems expert, an international and a national impact 
pathways and innovations systems expert, an international and a national communications 
scientist, a policy expert, a value chain and business model specialist, and a production and 
agro-industrial supply chain expert. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 3.  
23.  IRRI will procure laboratory equipment for the pre-harvest activities and goods and 
related services for the construction of postharvest technology prototypes in accordance with 
ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). At the end of the project, 
equipment procured and constructed under the TA will be turned over to the NARES partners.  
24.  Disbursement under the TA will be undertaken in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook 10 
25.  IRRI will disseminate the outputs and feedback on the progress made in achieving the 
project outcome and impact through websites, the media, periodic meetings with concerned 
stakeholders, rice-related networks, and publications.  
V.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
26.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for Addressing the Pre- and 
Postharvest Challenges of the Rice Supply Chain.

timely delivery of quality outputs. Ensure that gender concerns are taken into 
account.

fertilizer regimes.

training.

(i)  Monitor  the  virulence  and  spread  of  plant  hopper  transmitted  viruses,  and 
develop management methods to reduce the spread of the virus.

data.  
(iv)  Provide technical advice on findings and recommendations, and prepare reports 
for integration into the overall report for the pre-harvest subproject. 
(v)  Collaborate  with  the  national  agriculture  research  and  extension  systems 
(NARES) in information sharing and transfer of technical skills and know how.   
 
5.  Insecticide toxicologist (international, 4 person-months) 
 
(i)  Conduct training in advanced toxicology and probit analysis. 
(ii)  Analyze cumulated data from various project sites in the participating DMCs, and 
determine bases of insecticide resistance. 
(iii)  Document and maintain records of data on insecticide resistance levels across 
project sites in participating DMCs.  
(iv)  Provide technical advice on findings and recommendations, and prepare reports 
for integration into the overall report for the preharvest subproject.

(v)  Collaborate with the NARES in information sharing and transfer of technical skills

baseline data and post-intervention changes, and to monitor the impact of the 
subproject's outputs on farmers’ pest management decisions.  
(ii)  Conduct gender analysis of the direct and indirect roles in pesticide application

(iii)  Conduct  policy  dialogues  with  concerned  government  agencies  and  other 
stakeholders. 
(iv)  Provide expert advice on procedures in conducting policy engagements.
